General Orders, no. 47.
div3.p: I. The reception of unnaturalized foreigners as Substitutes in the army is hereby forbidden.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
(Signed) S. Cooper,
jy 5--1w Adj't and Insp'r General,

div3.head:
Headq's 3d brigade Huger's Div'n,
camp near Melvin Hill,
July 4, 1862.
special Orders, no.--
div3.p:
All officers, non-commissioned officers, and privates of this command who are absent from their companies and regiments, are required to return to duty immediately, or they will be published in the Richmond and Georgia papers as deserters.
Those who are really sick will send to these headquarters a surgeon's certificate of their condition.
No brave officer or private will skulk from duty in such a time as this.
Cowards alone hug the city or wagon camps when their comrades are gallantly confronting the insolent foe and driving him from our soil.
div3.closer:
By order of Brig. Gen. Wright.
V. J. B. Girardy,
jy 5--3t* A. A. General.

div3.head: To members of 8th Georgia Reg't in Richmond.
div3.p:
--All members of the regiment in this city without authority, are requested immediately to return to camp.
In this great exigency no private or officer of the 8th Georgia should leave his colors without the severest necessity, and will be expected in all cases to have complete official authority for doing so. Being confined to my bed, and not in command, I can only appeal to the patriotism of my men, and desire every one not severely ill or wounded to stand fast by the regimental colors.
div3.closer:
Lucius M. Lamar.
jy 5--2t* Col. of 8th Reg't Ga. Vols.

div3.p:
To the sick and wounded soldiers from Alabama, now in Private Residences, Boarding-houses, or. Hotels, the undersigned offer their services.
One may always be found at the office of Maj. Vandevier, Alabama Depot, on Main st., above 9th.
div3.closer:
E. A. Semple, M. D.,
W. C. Jackson, M. D.,
J. T. Johnston, M. D.,
jy 5--6t* R. S. Williams, M. D.

div3.p:
Second Lieut. James Garrity, Company E, 5th La. Reg't, is badly wounded, and any member of his company seeing this advertisement will please call and see him, at "Chimborazo Hospital," Church Hill, Div. No.
"1," Ward "H," No. 12.
jy 5--3t*

div4.p: From an accident upon the Danville Railroad Thursday, the 3d instant, George Merwi youngest son of Horace L. and Elizabeth F. the 18th year of his age.
The friends of the family are requested to his funeral from the residence of his father this (Saturday) morning the 3th instant at 9 o'clock.
On Thursday, 3d inst., at 10 o'clock P. M., Jacob Hall, Sit., in the 81st year of his age.

His friends and those of his sons Richard and Jacob Hall, Jr., and of his sons-in-law.
Thou R. Price and Wm. Marchall, are invited to attest his funeral from the residence of J. Hall.
Jr. (corns Leigh and 7th streets,) this morning at 10 ½ o'clock
Mobile papers please copy.
On Friday, the 27th of June, William Gilm son of A. P. Giles, of Albemarle, Va. in the year of his age.
A member of the 12th regiment Virginia volunteers, he fell while gallantly charging the enemy breastworks, in the battle of Gaines's Mill, and died instantly.

At the residence of John.
H. Gilmer, Esq. brother-in-law.
James M. Anderson.
His funeral will take place from St. James Church, this afternoon at 6 o'clock.
On the 3d inst., of wounds received on the T. McLAUGHLIN, of 3d Alabama Regiment
Mobile papers please copy.

div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p:
How uncertain is Life!
how certain is Man is like a flower — now in the bud; now vigor of bloom, springing up as if by magic, cut down by the chilly frost, which has just from the lap of wintry death, man dies, passes away, and is no more!
Yet who can meas are depth of the heast anguish of the loved ones when the idol of the household is consigned to the Loud and deep is the orphan's wail and anguish as their pride and hope leaves them to eternity!
In a spirit of deep condolence pour a balm of consolation in the heart of the and afflicted widow and orphan.

Sergeant John M. Duke was killed in the He of Port Republic on the 8th of June, 1862. 32d year of his age, leaving a wife and interesting child.
In that spirit that characterized near all Virginia's sons, Mr. Dake rallied to the defence Liberty; and as he lived, so did he die, a patriet molating himself as a bloody sacrifice upon the of his country.
He died proudly — aye, grandly the soldier ever wishes to die amid the four shock of territic battle, at his gun, and in the charge of his duty.
He was a member of Courthey (Va.) Artillery.

His was a noble soul, a loving husband, and and doting father, a consistent Christian and his death he was released from trials, and now gone to a happy re union in Heaven with his des babes, for "blessed are the dead that die in Lord." He was beloved by all who know him though he can return to us no more, we can go him in blest eternity. [*] Mrs. M. C.

Killed, on the 1st of July, while gallantly testing his company, foremost in the charge.
Captian Dennis Vermillion, of the "Old Domind Guard," Company K, 9th Va. Vols., in the year of his age.

Among the first to volunteer, he resigned a ernment position and entered the service nearly fifteen months ago. Acting bravely at the of Seven Pines, and having many of his wounded, he was constantly on duty till the hour of his death.
Yet, broken down, wearied as was, his spirits never failed him, and the evening of his fall he bid his men let none be abead of them in the charge.
Right nobly did they resposed to the call, but in his death have paid dearly their heroism.
"Lay his sword by his side, it hath served him well
Not to rest near his pillow below;
To the last moment true, from his hand ere and
Its point was still turned to the foe.
Killed, whilst gallantly leading his men to on Friday, June 27, Capt. William H. Randolph, Company D, 5th Regiment Virginia Volunteers.

No death that has occurred during the more to be lamented than that of Capt. Randolps.
The writer of this shared his friendship from the 18th of April, 1861, till the time of his death been with him in every battle — and now melancholy pleasure in being able to mention feeble praise, the many merits of one of Virginia most devoted patriots and bravest sons.
No in the "Stonewall Brigade" was more beloved by both officers and men. To his brother officer was always the courteous gentleman — to the a most kind and efficient friend.
He never regarded rank in the army, but patronized merit places; and the entire heart of the regiment deeply and laments bitterly their loss.
W. M.

Fell, in the brilliant engagement of July vate Joseph Berger, of the Baltimore Artillery.
At the commencement of the struggle for Southern independence, and when chains of the Federal despotism were oncireling people of his beloved State, young Berger, mon with thousands of others, bade adien native city of Baltimore and volunteered vices in the "Lanter Guard," 13th Virginia ment, but was subsequently transferred Baltimore Light Artillery.
He fell in the thicks of the fight and in the faithful discharge of duty, menifesting remarkable coolness and intapidity in the hour of danger.
He was highly teemed among his comrades in arms who bore from the field and carefully interred his remains.
This gallant young man sealed his derection erty with his life; and although his name may emblazon the page of history, a nation a ing gratitude, will (make a pilgrim's of as grave.
Died, at the St. Charles Hotel Hospital on the 8th of June, of typhoid fever, in the 19th year his age, Isaac Augustus Hughes of Herver county, Va., a member of Capt. Carter's William Artillery.

At the call of his native State, this noble tearing asunder all the ties that bound him to and bidding adieu to a most devoted father and ther and affectionate brothers and sisters volunteered and left for the seene of war. After ing the toils of a year's service, he was down with disease but a few days before the of the Seven Tines, in which his company suffers so heavily and covered themselves with glory the many victims of this war, no more affection son and brother or truer hearted soldier has up his life on the altar of his country.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 23, Number 5, page 3.

div3.head: The battles below Richmond.

argument.p: situation of affairs — reported Surrounding of the enemy — Featherstone's brigade — incidents of the conflict, &c. &c.

div3.p:
There is nothing of exciting interest to report relative to the situation of affairs yesterday, nor has there been any sanguinary engagement between the contending armies since the great conflict of Tuesday last.
A telegraphic dispatch was received at this office yesterday morning from Chester, communicating the important intelligence that a large portion of the army of McClellan was surrounded by our forces at Carter's Mill Pond, in Charles City county, and that our cavalry captured a large lot of wagons and other property at Shirley.
We have information that a portion of our army took up the line of march on Thursday night, with the supposed view of flanking the enemy, and it is by no means improbable that the desired result has been achieved.
It is the opinion of some military men, who have entire confidence in the skill and vigilance of our military commanders, that a decisive blow will be struck before the enemy has an opportunity to escape, while others, assuming that McClellan has still a numerous army confronting our forces, believe that he will continue his retreat to the mouth of the Chickahominy, and there make a stand under protection of Yankee gunboats.
Intelligence, deemed entirely authentic, was received last evening that our pickets had captured two couriers attempting to make their way to McClellan, with dispatches directing him to hold out for two days longer, by which time be would have ample reinforcements.--The possession of this information may lead to speedy operations on the part of our army.

At last accounts a large fleet of Federal gunboats and transports were lying — between Berkeley and Westover.
No firing was heard on the river yesterday morning.
Before leaving Shirley the Yankees robbed Mr. Carter, the owner of the estate, of all his stock.

div4.head: Phis of the enemy on Thursday.
div4.p:
A member of Stuart's Cavalry, who left the scene of operations on Thursday afternoon, informs us that the mass of the diminished army was then at Westover, on the north side of James river, some thirteen miles below City Point.
McClellan's headquarters were at Berkeley.
There were none of the enemy at Shirley.
Our informant ascended a bluff, and saw twenty five Federal transports, and on Wednesday another gentleman counted 150, all beading up the river.
The Jeff. Davis Legion (Col. Martin) took 150 prisoners on Wednesday evening, one man alone capturing 25.

div4.head: The latest.
div4.p: I was reported by a gentleman who came up last night, that about 100 vessels were near Berkeley, and that a large force of the Federals was gathered there.

It was rumored last night that the Confederate gunboat Teazer, while on a reconnoissance down the river, was captured by one of the enemy's ships.
The Teazer was originally a tugboat and carries two guns.

div4.head: Artillery Duel.
div4.p:
An engagement took place on Thursday morning between Pelham's Battery, of Stuart's Horse Artillery, and a battery of the enemy's rifled guns.
On our side there were only two small brass pieces, but they kept up a vigorous fire until their ammunition was exhausted when they withdrew from the contest. A body of cavalry was then deployed as skirmishers in the woods and the Federal battery was thus held in check until its ammunition also gave out, when the firing ceased.
The enemy's gunboats attempted to cooperate during the engagement, and threw some shells in direction of our forces; but neither they are the rifled guns on land, inflicted any damage.

div4.head: The affair on Sunday.
div4.p:
Much has been said about an affair on Sunday evening last, through which some valuable lives were sacrificed by the lamentable mistake of two bodies of our troops firing into each other.
We are satisfied, however, from a conversation with a gentleman who participated in this engagement, that no such disaster occurred as we have alluded to, although, through some misapprehension, it was then thought otherwise.

It appears that about half an hour before sunset on Sunday evening a battery of four pieces, posted near the point where a bridge crosses the railroad, some eight or nine miles below Richmond, was firing into a body of the enemy stationed near a skirt of woods in an easterly direction, when the 21st and 17th Mississippi regiments were ordered up to support the artillery.
The 17th fired two rounds and the 21st five, when word came to them to cease, as they were firing upon their own friends!
The Mississippians at once sent messengers to have the return fire discontinued, but it so happened that these messengers invariably came upon one of our own regiments, the 8th Georgia, we believe, posted a little to the right, and the answer was as often returned that they were not firing into their friends, but into the enemy.
Nevertheless, the order was peremptory that the Mississippi regiments must reserve their fire, and they therefore lay upon the ground until after dark receiving volley after volley, but unable to reply.
The next morning the field where the supposed friends were stationed was visited, and about 100 dead and 200 wounded Yankees, belonging to a Vermont regiment, were found.--It thus appears evident that the mistake attributed to a portion of our gallant troops in reality never occurred, though it is unfortunate that such a misapprehension of the situation of affairs existed at the time.

div4.head: Gallant conduct.
div4.p:
Adjutant R. T. Daniel, Jr., lies severely wounded at home in this city.
Being absent on leave from Gen. Marshall's army, he went into the battles before Richmond as volunteer Aid to General Armistead, and in the severe conflict on Tuesday last was in command of a company.
The color- bearer of the 38th Virginia regiment having fallen, the colors were taken by the Lieutenant- Colonel, who was also shot down.
Adjutant Daniel then took them, and while rushing into the conflict he received three gunshot wounds in succession--one in the breast, another in the arm, and a third in the thigh, which knocked him down.
We are gratified to state that none of his wounds are considered mortal.

div4.head: Gen. Griffith, of Mississippi.
div4.p:
This gallant officer, whose death has heretofore been announced, was near the enemy's fortifications on the north side of the York River Railroad, about half-past 11 o'clock on Sunday, when a fragment of a shell thrown at our locomotive battery struck him above the right knee, ranging upwards, and almost destroying his thigh.
Notwithstanding the fearful nature of his injuries, he lived for several hours after the occurrence, and expired at a private residence in this city.

div4.head: Destructions of Yankee stores.
div4.p:
We hear that the destruction of stores near West Point, by the enemy, surpasses in extent that of any other locality on the lines below Richmond.
They were piled up in layers, with pins timber between, to the height of some thirty feet, and covering a space a quarter of a mile in longth.
The torch was then upplied, and everything completely destroyed.
Wagons were broken up so as to render them useless, and out of this immense mass of army supplies, nothing of value can be saved.
From other points, however, between the Paman key river and Richmond, a considerable amount has been received, and more is daily arriving.
Up to yesterday morning twelve thousand stond of arms and several fine rifled cannon had been brought to the Government Arsenal, and a long train of wagons, heavily loaded, arrived late in the afternoon.

A valuable locomotive, left by the Yankees near the Chickahominy river, reached this city last evening, in a somewhat damaged condition.
The train brought up at the same time a large lot of ammunition, which the enemy attempted to destroy before leaving, but failed in their purpose.

div4.head: Fifteenth Virginia regiment.
div4.p:
The Fifteenth regiment, composed of companies from this city and neighborhood, was in the severe battle of the 1st instant.
The casulties are as follows: Col. Thos. P. August, wounded, Major John Stewart Walker, killed.
Company A--Corporal J. B. Dodd, severaly wounded by the bursting of shell, Privates H. Schwalmeyer and George W. Brooke, wounded slightly.
Company B--Private Wm. M. Marshall, slightly. Company D--Privates August Harris and Benj. Faudre, slightly.
Company E--Private Thomas J. Barnett, severely. Company H--Corporal Wm. H. Dean and Wm. H. Holmes, slightly.

div4.head: Capture of Yankee Barbarians.
div4.p:
Four Yankees captured a Confederate soldier on Thursday and deliberately-- hunged him to a tree, having pinned upon his back a card inscribed, "We hang all the rebels we catch." The miscreants were immediately afterward captured by a squad of our cavalry, and were yesterday brought to the city in company with a negro owned by Capt. White.
We are surprised, that summary punishment was not inflicted upon them on the spot.

div4.head: Admissions of prisoners.
div4.p:
Among the prisoners is a member of a Massachusetts regiment, who remained behind when the Grand Army took its fright, with the praise worthy purpose of nursing the sick Yankees in the hospital at Meadow Station, on the York River Railroad.
He seemed very desirous of entering into conversation with a party of gentlemen who visited that place a day or two since, and his loquacity proved him to be something of a Sir Oracle among his fellows.
Great was his astonishment, according to his own account, to find the spirit of "Secesh" so rampant in Virginia; he had been led to believe that a vast majority of the people were anxious to return to their allegiance, and were only waiting for McClellan's arrival to throw off the yoke imposed upon them by Jeff Davis and his followers.
This, he said, was the general impression throughout the Federal ranks; and if he were only once more safe at home, he would never be caught in such a trap again.
This man, and others of the party (one of whom claimed to be a native of Richmond), freely acknowledged that McClellan's army had suffered a most disastrous rout.

div4.head: The New York Seventh.
div4.p:
In the first visit of the New York Seventh Regiment to Virginia they were feted and treated with the hospitality characteristic of Virginia.
They came then as an escort to the remains of an honored son of the Old Dominion and a former beloved Chief Magistrate of the United States.
On their second visit, being united with thieves and vagabonds in a maranding and plundering expedition against, their hosts, they were also appropriately received.
It is said, and we have no reason to doubt the fact, that on going over the battle field after the contest three days since, below this city, 390 members of the famous "New York Seventh" were found hors de combat. It was just retribution for ingratitude on their part, blacker specimens of which have rarely been exhibited.

div4.head: Arrival of prisoners.
div4.p:
An addition was made yesterday to the floating population of the city by the arrival of 250 "Federal soldiers, taken in one of the recent engagements below this city.
While there were some very fine specimens of well developed manhood in this aggregate of human depravity, the majority were not calculated, from their appearance, to produce any favorable impressions.
The following officers arrived at the same time; C. M. Hildebrand, 1st Lieut. co. G, 5th Pa.; W. J. Harrison, 1st Lieut. co. C, 7th N. J.; C. M. Angell, Captain co. E, 61st N. Y; Wm. C. Besseliever, Captain co. D, 4th Pennsylvania; Jas. M. Leonard, Aid-de-Camp to Gen. Birney; D. E. Gregory, 1st Lieut. and Adjutant 61st New York.

div4.head: Accident to Gen. Pendleton.
div4.p: We regret to learn that this distinguished officer, while giving an order to Capt. Rogers, on Thursday last, received a severe kick on the foot from one of his battery horses, which will unfit the General for active duty forseveral days.

div4.head: Stolen Bible recovered.
div4.p:
A member of company D. 2d Mississippi battalion, has caused to be sent to this office for restoration to its proper owner, a copy of the Holy Bible, taken, as he says, with the assistance of an Enfield ball, from the knapsack of a defunct Yankee in the engagement of the 27th inst. By the vandal's own story (on the register page of the book,) it was stolen from the residence of Dr. Frederick Power, at Yorktown, who no doubt values it very highly, as it contains his family records.
The inscription put on the register by the dead Hessian reads as follows:

q.p:
"Mr. George Wylie, private in the 62 Penna. Volunteers, company K, in the taking of Yorktown Va. May 4th 1862 after a charge banet on the water battery and threw the town, stakt arms in the street to draw a breath; Some of us boys went into the discarted houses, and this holy bible was the first book caught my eye, and I lifted it (!!) and seen it was this holy book.
I could not feel to leave it down to be destroyed, but put it into my haversack, and till we returned to camp winfield scott whare I act down to present it to my little nephew George Dun, in memory of his uncle George Wylie, the second company to enter into Yorktown the year of our Lord 1862, 4th May."

div4.p: The circumstances attending the larceny being thus narrated by the principal actor, and his fate ascertained, we will only add the words inscribed under private Wylie's effusion by the party who helped to recover the property stolen by him, which read as follows:

q.p:
"Retaken, June 27th, 1862, by a member of company D, 21 batt.
Miss. Vols. and respecifully returned to the owner, Dr. Power, through the Richmond Dispatch office."

div4.p: Inscribed on the fly leaf of the sacred volume, in the handwriting of the owner, appears the following:

q.p: "The angel of the Lord encampeth around about them who fear him, and delivereth them.
"Blessed is the man unto whom the Lord imputeth not iniquity, and in whose spirit there is no guile.
"The eyes of the Lord are upon the righteous, and his ears are open unto their cry."

div4.p: In concluding this notice, we may remark that the wife of Dr. F. W. Power, is a daughter of Garland Hanes, Esq., of Henrico, who has lost one or more sons in the present contest.

div4.head: Gen. Featherstone's brigade.
div4.p:
Gen. Featherstone was wounded on Monday evening. It was his third light with his brigade, comprising the 19th and 12th Mississippi and the 2d Mississippi battalion.
He was struck by a grapeshot in the left shoulder, shattering his collar-bone.
He remained on the field after he was wounded until the fortunes of the day were decided.
Gen. Featherstone, we learn, is now at the Arlington House, improving slowly.
As his deeds of gallantry have made him conspicuous in our late fights, we will give the following sketch of his life, which we know to be correct:

Winfield Scott Featherstone is a native of Virginia.
He is about 12 or 13 years of age. When he left Virginia, he settled in Chickasaw county, Miss., for the practice of the law. He was elected to Congress in 1817, and served until 1851, when being an ardent Secessionist at that time, he was defeated, along with our present illustrious Chief Magistrate, who was in the same year candidate for Governor of Mississippi.
Since that time he has been practicing law in Holly Springs, justly regarded as one of the brightest intellects, and as recent events have shown, one of the bravest and most daring of the gallant sons of the Magnolia State.
His Adjutant General, Capt. Geo. P. Foote, a most estimable gentlemen, was killed in the fight of Friday evening.--The remainder of his staff, Major J. M. Part ridge, (for the Vicksburg Whig.) Major W. R. Barksdale, Lieuts. Parker and Sykes, escaped unhurt.
We hear that the mortality in this brigade was fearful.
Every field officer except one is disabled, Major W. Sidney Wilson, of the 2d Mississippi battalion, who is now in command of the brigade, or what is left of it. There are but three captains left in the brigade, and but four lieutenants, and the enlisted men, all told, do not number five hundred.
Truly has our gallant Southwestern sister nobly defended the Capital of the Confederacy.
Among the killed, we regret to learn, is Col. John G. Taylor, of the 2d Mississippi battalion.
He was a relative of "Old Zach," which name he answered to a mongst his friends, and was one of the most gallant officers in the service.

div4.head: From the Southside.
div4.p: The Petersburg Express, of yesterday, contains the following intelligence:

q.p:
The enemy for several days past have been much jaded and partially demoralized.
It is estimated that as many as three or four thousand were loitering about the banks of the river in the vicinity of Shirley, Charles City county, on Tuesday last.
A party who came from Shirley and reached Bermuda Hundreds on Wednesday night; gives this information.
We learn from the same source that immense numbers of the killed and wounded were brought to Shirley.
The latter, many of them, embarked at this point on the enemy's transports for Fortress Monroe, and several of the dead were buried there.
A gentleman informs' us that the bodies of eight dead Yankees were lying in the yard of the fine mansion at Shirley on Wednesday morning, awaiting interment.

Quite a panic occurred among the fugitives in the vicinity of Shirley, on Wednesday morning. A fleeing Yankee came in and reported that the "rebels were coming," when a stampede ensued, which our informant states would have been ludicrous but for the pitiable and famished condition of the men. Many divested themselves of all wearing apparel save pants and caps, and rushed wildly into the swamps and bogs back of Eppes's Island, and at times some of them were up to their arm-pits in the water.
Others seized all the boats they could place their hands upon and put out for the opposite banks, or into the many coves and inlets with which the river abounds.
Mr. Carter, we hear, loses eleven boats, every one he had, while all his neighbors shared a similar fate.

A free man of color crossed over to Bermuda Hundreds, Wednesday night; bringing some seventy or eighty very valuable coats, jackets and pants, (as many as his boat could hold) which he gathered up at Shirley.
He states that some two hundred wagons or more which were at Shirley, were also abandoned, the drivers sharing in the panic, and leaving their horses without hesitation.
These will all fall into the possession of our army.

The refugee who swam over from Shirley Tuesday night, and was taken prisoner by our pickets at Bermuda Hundreds, proved to be a member of the New York Fifty-fifth regiment, named Cooper.
He was of prepossessing appearance, and quite intelligent.--He represented General McClellan as being greatly worsted in the series of battles in which he had engaged, and that the men for the most part were heartily tired of the war. He stated, however, that he was not a deserter; but that he had heard Burnside was on the south bank of the James river, and he came over for the purpose of getting something to eat, and, if possible, a little sleep — both of which essentials he represented himself as standing greatly in need of. Our pickets, commiserating his condition, gave him food and raiment, and sent him to headquarters at Drewry's Bluff.
The four prisoners who came over in a boat the night before, were also sent up to Drewry's Bluff. One of them proved to be an impertinent Yankee, and expressed no regret at having participated in this wicked and unholy invasion.

Parties reached Petersburg yesterday at mid-day who left the vicinity, of Gen. Lee's headquarters early yesterday morning.
They state that they crossed over at a point opposite Drewry's Bluff, and were thus enabled to reach Petersburg in a few hours.
These men bring an important piece of information, which they asseverate most solemnly to be correct.
They state that Gen. Lee was visited early yesterday morning by a flag of truce, bearing a letter from Gen. McClellan, the purport of which was that he, (Gen. McC.,) being hotly pursued, had been compelled to abandon some 4,000 or more of his sick and wounded; that they were at certain points which were named; that Gen. Lee would find some 200 tens of ice at one place, and an abundance of medical stores at another: that he had left these men in charge of surgeons, and as both the Confederate and Federal Governments had agreed to regard surgeons as non- combatants, he hoped Gen. Lee would respect them, and not treat them as prisoners of war. The Federal General very politely closed his letter by stating, that should an opportunity ever occur, it would afford him great pleasure to reciprocate the kindness which he had solicited at General Lee's hands.

We do not vouch for the correctness of this statement, but it comes to us in such a manner that we think it entitled to credit, and give it for the benefit of our readers.
If correct, these sick and wounded are prisoners of war, and when well will be exchanged as such.

Persons of the highest respectability state that the train of wagons at Berkeley, to which we have twice before alluded, is still there, and that it is hourly increasing in numbers.
They now stretch out along the banks of the river for miles, and stand in rows three or four deep.
Yesterday, all the gunboats and transports which had been up in the neighborhood of Shirley and Curles's Neck on Tuesday and Wednesday, had dropped down in the vicinity of Berkeley, and were passing up and down shelling the woods in that section.
One man who has viewed these wagons from across the river, a distance of about one urile, estimates them at 6,000.
This is doubtless an exaggeration, but all who have seen them state their probable number at a very high figure.
It is conjectured by some as probable that McClellan contemplates making Berkeley a base of operations for another "onward march to Richmond," and therefore he is causing his wagons and other valuables to be congregated at this point.
The water here is very deep, affording fine anchorage for his transports and gunboats, and is about equidistant between Newport News and Richmond by water.
This is mere conjecture, but it does seem a little remarkable that he should expose so much valuable material at Berkeley, unless he contemplated protecting it in some way. It may be that he relies on his gunboats for protection until he can find more leisure to remove it than has been at his disposal recently.

Later.--A gentleman reached here yesterday evening direct from Curle's Neck, Henrico county, via Drewry's Bluff.
He states that the enemy abandoned Curle's Neck Tuesday night, leaving a vast amount of fixed ammunition, over twenty field pieces, several tons of ice, fresh meats, and other valuable provisions.
They evidently left in a great hurry, and made no effort to destroy these valuables.
The articles are well guarded, and will be immediately placed in a place of safety.

Our pickets at Hood's, a short distance below City Point, captured yesterday morning five more Yankees, who came across the river at that point from McClellan's fleeing army, and voluntarily surrendered themselves.

They were in the best possible humor when brought here, and seemed to rejoice at their capture.
They report themselves as tired and disgusted with the war, and say they have been deceived as to the object of it and promises made regarding it. They say there are hundreds and thousands in McClellan's Grand Army who would be glad of an opportunity to surrender themselves to the Confederates.
This information is no doubt correct.

div3.head: Runaway.
div3.p:
--$20 reward for a negro Girl named Emma, the property of W. H. Meredith, Esq. She is 17 years of age, dark skin, and has a scar on her wrist about two inches long, and is about 5 feet high.
Said Girl has runaway several times in the last two months, and when found had hired herself in the employment of hotels; therefore, hotel and hospital stewards are requested to employ the said Girl.
I will give the above reward if delivered to Robert Lumpkins's Robert Meredith.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 23, Number 5, page 4.

div3.head: The noble Women of Richmond.
div3.p: --We saw a day or two since, a most touching and beautiful letter, addressed by a lady of Richmond to the father of a volunteer from this State, giving an account of the sickness and death of his son. He was a mere boy, and his gentle and delicate appearance, as he lay in the hospital, having attracted the attention of some ladies, they had him removed to their house, and kindly nursed and ministered to him until he died.

We mention this case among thousands of a similar kind which have no doubt occurred in Richmond.
Sorely pressed by the enemy, with almost famine prices for nearly every odible they purchase, with but few if any luxuries and delicacies, with the sounds and alarms of war around them, and with their own sons and brothers and husbands in the army, these noble women see devoting themselves to the sick and the wounded from every State who are thrown among them, with a patience, fortitude, and unwearied particularity of attention, and with a forgetfulness of their own ease and comfort, which call for the thanks and gratitude of all Southerners, and which will make their names immortal in the history of this war. Every father, and mother, and wife, and sister, and brother, in all these Confederate States, whose near and dear ones have been succored and cared for by these "ministering angels," will "rise up and call them blessed." The brave men who encircle Richmond as with a wall of are, are no doubt deeply sensible of the attention thus shown by the noble women of Richmond to their sick and wounded comrades, and the knowledge that they are fighting for such women and for such families, as well as for their own firesides, will give tenfold vigor to their efforts in the day of battle.--Raleigh Standard.

div3.head: Jokes on the "Rebels."
div3.p: --The following from the budget of jokes in the Boston Wide World may be enjoyed with particular satisfaction just new:
The Southerners should have their baggage marked for extensive route this session.
The kind of "his" the rebels give our boys — the abominable uniforms they leave in their camps.
The rebel army is like an inveterate coquette: it backs out from all engagements.
"Up boys!" cries Jeff. Davis--"each man to his gun;
Show these Yankees your knapsacks, you'll soon make them run;
We have sworn, like brave Southerners, that something we'll beat--
If we can't beat the Yankees, we'll beat the retreat."
A Southern paper calls the Federal blockade "a mning outrage" --probably because it exercises such a bale-full influence on the cotton warehouses, or tharabouts."

div3.head: Taking prisoners Prayed out.
div3.p: --The following paragraph taken from the Philadelphia Inquirer will serve as a hint to our own men:

q.p:
"The notorious Missouri rebel, Col. John Owens, who made himself conspicuous in burning bridges, and depots, and by firing into passenger trains, last summer and fall, was last week hunted down by a detachment of sent out from Palmyra.
They found him near his farm, and, after a slight resistance on his part, they succeeded in capturing him. Preparations were made for his execution.
He begged the soldiers to take him prisoner, They informed him that 'taking prisoners' was played out. They then placed him upon a stump, in front of a file of soldiers, and, at the word of command, eight bullets pierced the body of the rebel, killing him instantly."

div3.head: Water drinking.
div3.p:
--Improper drinking of water has killed thousands. There have been instances where thirsty armies, after long marches, have come to some river, when the men would lie down on their faces and quaff an inordinate quantity of water, with these results: some died almost instantly, others became crazy, and staggered like drunken men. Avoid drinking water as much as possible while marching.
When you feel dry, rinse the mouth with water, but do not swallow it. Drink only when resting, or before the word is given to march.
Men when heated should not drink anything cold.
In a state of perspiration, ice-water only aggravates thirst.
Drink slowly; half a tumbler of water will suffice the thirstiest man in the world, if he drinks by sips.
Take from twenty-five to one hundred sips, and swallow each time — it will quench thirst better than a quart drank in the usual manner.
In fact, it is almost impossible to get down a full glass of water taken in this way.

div3.head: Japanese Tommy.
div3.p: --A London letter to the Chicago Journal says:

q.p:
"The Japanese Ambassadors visited the Exhibition a few days ago, and seemed quite at home in the American department, where they met some persons whom they had before seen in New York.
Mr. Holmes inquired after the health of 'Tommy,' whom you will remember as quite a pet in the United States, and was informed that he was dead; but the announcement was made with bursts of excessive laughter, and it is supposed that that individual, owing to some misdemeanor, had shuffled off the mortal coil by the method known in Japan as the 'happy dispatch.'"

div3.head: A long Sermon.
div3.p:
--We saw a good anecdote the other day about long preaching.
A lady took her son of some five or six years to church.
After the minister had been preaching half an hour, the little fellow grew sleepy and began to nod. The mother roused him into attention several times by pinching.
But, as it seemed a hopeless ease, she concluded to let him sleep undisturbed.
After the little fellow had his nap out, he awoke, and still saw the minister holding forth.
He looked up in his mother's face and innocently asked: "Mother, is it this Sunday night, or is it next Sunday night?"

div3.head: To hire
div3.p:
--A servent Girl, for remainder of the year, or by the month.
She is a good nurse, seamstress, and general housemaid.
She washes and irons tolerably well.
Apply at Mr. Wm. Nott's, on south side of Clay, between 2d and 3d streets, near centre of square.

div3.head: Negroes for hire.
div3.p:
--We have five or six Women for hire.
Several can cook, wash, and iron.
We would hire them to work in any of the hospitals that can furnish them with a place to sleep.
We have also a likely Boy, about 10 years old, for hire.
Clopton & Lyne, Agents,
jy 4--2t Office corner Wall and Franklin sts.

div3.head:
Office Chief Quarterm'r, army
of Northwestern Virginia.
corner Bank and 10 sts., Richmond, Va.
div3.p:
it being represented that teamsters are committing depredations on the farms adjacent to Richmond, citizens are requested to find out the names of the teamsters, the regiment to which they belong, and the wagon master in charge of the teams.
If a report, properly subst antiated, is made to me, the person or persons offending will be punished.
It is my desire to pitten stop to these depredations, and it can only be done in the manner above prescribed.
div3.closer:
Jas. L. Cooley,
jy 4--1w Lieut. Col, and Chief Quarterm'r.

div3.head: Six dollars reward.
div3.p:
--A reward of $6 will be paid for the apprehension and delivery of a negro girl named Amey.
She is a bright mulatto, with long hair, broad, full features, low stature, and quite fleshy.
She was at Bellevue Hospital on Sunday and Monday nights last.
A. B. Owen.
jy 4--3t* Mayo street, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Negro Boy, Pat, Missing.
div3.p:
--Got separated from me on the march from Williamsburg, my Negro Boy, Pat; aged 19; about five feet eight inches high; black and well formed.
I will pay a suitable reward if delivered to me at the camp of the 3d Va. Cavalry, or at the Provost Marshal's, in Richmond.
W. N. F. Jones,
jy 4--3t* Third Virginia Cavalry.

div3.head:
C. S. Navy Department,
Richmond, June 24, 1862.
div3.p: A Naval General Court Martial is hereby ordered to convene at the city of Richmond, Virginia, on the 5th day of July, 1862, or as soon thereafter as practicable, for the trial of Flag Officer Josiah Tattnall, and of such other persons as may be legally brought before it.
The Court will be composed of the following officers, any five of whom are empowered to act, viz:
Captain Lawrence Rousseau,
Captain Franklin Buchanan,
Captain Sydney S. Lee,
Commander Robert G. Robb,
Commander Murray Mason,
Commander Eben Farrand,
Commander A. B. Fairfak,
Commander M. F. Maury,
Commander Geo. Minor,
Lieutenant Wm. L. Maury,
Lieutenant Robert B. Pegram; and Robert Ould is hereby appointed the Judge Advocate.
The above being the greatest number of officers that can be convened without manifest injury to the service.
div3.closer:
S. R. Mallory,
Secretary of the Navy.
The Court will meet at 12 o'clock M., at the Navy Department. je 26--tJy5th

div3.head: Headq'rs Va. State Line, Wytheville, June 30th, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No.--

The men whose names are hereunto appended, members of a company commanded by Captain St. Martin, are hereby dismissed and expelled the service of the State of Virginia.
There is strong ground to believe that these men are all deserters from the Confederate Army, and, as such, are guilty of a crime disreputable to them as men and capital in the eye of military law. Their conduct whilst in camp here has been disgraceful to the services the general brutality of their conduct being aggravated by repeated acts of dishonesty and theft.
They are, therefore, dishonorably discharged from the service of the State of Virginia.

closer.signed: Major General Com'g Va. State Line.

div4.p: jy 4--1w

div3.head:
[Extract.]
war Department,
Adjutant and Inspector General's office,
Richmond, July 1, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 46.--

II. 4.
General Orders, No. 44, current series, is hereby rescinded, and the following paragraph is substituted in lieu thereof:

Persons under eighteen and over thirty-five years of age, who have re-enlisted for three years or the war, are not entitled to their discharge under the Conscript Act. Persons of the ages above mentioned, who enlisted for twelve months, or for a shorter term, will be entitled to their discharge ninety days after the expiration of their term of service.

III.
All chaplains taken prisoners of war by the armies of the Confederate States, while in the discharge of their proper duties, will be immediately and unconditionally released.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
(Signed,) S. Cooper,
jy 2--1w Adjutant and Inspector General.

div3.head:
War Department,
Adj't Inspector General's office,
Richmond, June 26, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 45.

list.item:
I. A General Intelligence Office, to enable the friends of the sick and wounded to find them out, to facilitate communication with the army, is here-by established.
Military Commanders and Surgeons will afford all the means in their power to promote the ends of its establishment.
II. Medical officers taken prisoners of war by the armies of the Confederate States will be immediately and unconditionally discharged.

III.
The Government of the United States having recognized the principle that medical officers should not be held prisoners of war, and having ordered the immediate and unconditional release of all medical officers so held, all medical officers of the Confederate States, now on parole, are hereby discharged from their parole.

div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
[Signed] S. Cooper.
je 27--1w Adj't and Inspect of General.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, June 19th, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 1, Prison Series.

list.item:
I. * * * * Capt. W. S. Winder. Ass't Adj't-General, is charged with all correspondence relative to Provost Marshal's Department and the prisons.
All communcations relating to them will be addressed accordingly.

II. * * * * Manchester and vicinity, including the whole of the bridges, will constitute a Provost Marshal's district--Capt. Henry Wietz, Assistant Provost Marshal, is assigned to the command.
He will have entire charge of all the bridges, and will give the necessary orders to the guard.

div3.p: IV. * * * * Whenever an arrest is made, the policeman making the arrest will be held responsible for all property taken from the person arrested, until it shall be deposited in some place designated by the Provost Marshal, and in no case shall such property be used without special permission from the General commanding, or from Maj. Griswold. Provost Marshal.
div3.closer:
By order of Brig.-Gen. John H. Winder.
je 21--ts L. R. Page, A. A. G.

div3.head: Deserters.
div3.p:
--The following named persons are deserters from my campany.
The usual reward of $30 will be paid if delivered to me, or my brigade.
I deem it useless to deseribe them, as they are known in Richmond and Manchester.
Palmer and Hatcherson are residents of Franklin county, Va.
Those left sick in Manchester will report immediately, or send me certificates from an army surgeon.
div3.closer:
Emmet W. Welsiger,
Capt. Manchester Artillery, Courtney's Batt'n,
je 28--54 7th Brigade, 3d Division.

div3.head:
Attention!
Marylanders.
div3.p:
--I have been authorized to Recruit for the 1st Maryland Regiment.
All Maryland men are earnestly solicited to rally around the little blue flag of their State, and add new trophies of triumph to those which already adorn its staff.
All Marylanders, now serving in any corps other than the Maryland Line are, at their option, entitled to be transferred to the Line.

Applications for this purpose should be made to Major Geo. H. Kyle, at the Headquarters, No. 14 Pearl street, or to myself.
A large amount of excellent clothing has just been forwarded to the regiment for gratuitous distribution, and all enlisting will receive the usual bounty of $50.

Eugene Digges, lately Lieut Md. Reg.
Office on Main, near the corner of Pearl street. Hours: From 10 A. M. to 2 P. M. je 24--1w*

div3.head: Attention, Martin's Artillery!
div3.p: --All members of this command who are absent without leave, will report at once to Camp Lee, or they will be reported to the Provost Guard and arrested as deserters.
Persons wishing to join the company will apply to Serg't Pulliam, at the recruiting office, corner of Bank and 12th streets.

I am authorized by the Governor to raise a regiment of Cavalry, to serve under Major-General Floyd.
Persons wishing to get up, or assist in getting up, companies for this regiment, can do so by seeing or writing to me at Richmond.
div3.closer:
J. E. Johnson,
(Late Colonel 9th Va. Cavalry,)
je 27--1m* Col. Cavalry, Floyd's Division.

div3.head: Harrison's Company — Elliott's City battalion.
div3.p:
--Conscripts and militiamen, of any age, who are fit for duty, will be received.
This Battalion will not be moved from the city.
Pay, $31 per month, clothing, rations and quarters furnished.
Recruiting Office — England & Bro.'s 9th and Main street.

div3.head: Absconded Slave--$25 reward.
div3.p:
--Left my place on James river, upper end of Henrico county, on Sunday last, June, 1862, without any cause, my Servant Man, Cornelius, commonly called Duck.
He is about 25 years of age, rather small well made, black, good teeth, likely, and no marks; about 5 feet 7 inches high.
He is no doubt lurking about Richmond or endeavoring employment as servant in some of the camps, having many acquaintances among the servants in Richmond, out in no other place.
For his safe delivery to Blair & Chamberlayne, or placed in jail so they get him, they will pay the above reward.
jy 4--6t John Wickham.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--The above reward will be paid for a negro woman by the name of Winney Morton, who ran off on Thursday morning, 3d of July. She is 5 feet high, stout built, jet black, talks very lady like, but looks grum.
She had on a hood bonnet, head tied up with a black silk handkerchief.
She has a sister living in Manchester, and a husband waiting upon Captain Sales in the army, and owned by Sampson Jones, of Richmond.
The above reward will be given, if lodged in jail.
ly 4--1w* J. W. Satterwhite.

div3.head: Runaway--Fifty dollars reward
div3.p:
--On Sunday, the 22d of June, my boy Stewart, a bright mulatto; about 5 feet 4 inches in height; 17 years of age. The said boy is supposed to have accompanied the army of Gen. Jackson when passing through Albemarle county.
The above reward will be paid if taken out of the county, and $10 if taken in the county.
Chas. S. Bowcock, M. D.,
jy 3--1w* Everettsville, Albemarle co., Va.

div3.head: Ten dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Left the residence of the subscriber, on Rocketts Hill, last week, my negro boy Henry.
He is about 19 years of age, black color, and low stature.
I think he is lurking around the camps and hiring himself to the soldiers as free.
Any information concerning him will be thankfully received, and the above reward paid for his, delivery to me at my stall in the Old Market, No. 27.
Frederick Brauer, Sr.

div3.head: Catch the runaway.--$20 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my farm, on the Brook Turnpike, four miles from Richmond, on yesterday morning, my man Mathew.
He is about 5 feet 8 inches high; rather thick set; has a brown skin; is somewhat hollow jawed; about 40 years of age; has a dull, sleepy look out of his eyes; had on blue cotton pantaloons, brown round jacket, and an old wool hat. He was raised in King George county, and may try to cross our lines in that direction.--Pickets, officers and citizens are hereby requested to arrest him. Achilles D. Johnson.

div3.head: Runaway
div3.p:
--From the undersigned, on Monday, the 23d day of June, 1862, a Negro Boy, named Albert.
Said Albert is about 13 years of age, nearly 5 feet 3 or 4 inches high, very black, and lisps when talking.
No marks upon his person remembered.
He is supposed to be employed in some of the camps near the city.
I will give a reward of $10 for the apprehension of said boy and his delivery to me at my residence, corner of Main and Foushee sts.
jy 2--6t* John D. Quarles.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, from the American Hotel, on Monday, the 9th inst., my negro boy William, who calls himself William May. Said boy is about 20 years old; five feet ten inches in height; of a bright ginger-bread color; very pleasant address, and neat appearance.
He was raised on the estate of the late Wm. G. Overton, of Hanover, and may be endeavoring to escape to the enemy in that vicinity.
I will give the above reward for his apprehension and delivery to me in Petersburg, or $75 if delivered to Messrs. J. L. Carrington & Co., American Hotel, Richmond, Va.
je 25--6t Edmund G. James.
Whig, Examiner and Enquirer copy three times.

div3.head: Five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my house, my House Servant Peter — a smart and active boy, about 17 years of age, accustomed to the house.
He may have hired himself out as a waitman.
His front teeth are defective.
Had on when he left a blue soldier's shirt, with breast jacket.
Complexion a dark brown, with hair closely trimmed.
He may be lurking about some of the camps.
Wm. Archer Cocke,
jy 1--4t* Leigh st., bet. 2d and 3d.

div3.head: Runaway
div3.p:
--From the 13th section of the Richmond and Danville Railroad, a Negro Boy, named John, belonging to Charles Thornton, of Caroline county.
He is of a gingerbread color, about 5 feet 10 inches in height, knock-kneed, and wears a truss.
He was barefooted when he left.
The legal reward will be paid for his return at the office of the company at Richmond, or at any station on the road.
je 30--6t

div3.head: Runaways.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from Second Section Richmond and Danville Railroad, the following Slaves.
The legal reward will be paid for their return at the office of the company in Richmond, or at any Station on the road — viz:
Washington; very dark, five feet nine or ten inches high; stammers a little when spoken to.
Nelson; stout built, dark color, five feet seven or eight inches high.
Thomas; yellow complexion, rather slow in his movements, five feet nine or ten inches high.
All the property of Wm. H. Buckner, of Caroline county, Va. je 27--ts

div3.head: 100 dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my store, on Tuesday, March 17th, my negro boy Lewis Washington.
He is a bright mulatto, thick set, about five feet high, 15 years old; had on when last seen a brown sack coat, brown pants, and a military cap. The above reward of $100 will be paid for his delivery to me.
S. S. Cottrell,
je 5--ts No. 129 Main st.

div3.head: Sixty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, about the 10th of March, a negro boy, William, and on the 17th of June, Abram.
William is 21 years old, dark, copper colored, with thick lips and bushy hair; is about five feet ten inches high, with no special marks recollected, except a rupture.
Abram is black; 17 years old; stoutly built; round face, and pleasing countenance; about five feet five or six inches high, and has a very large scar from vaccination, and possibly two. Fifty dollars will be given for William if taken out of the county, or $10 for William or Abram each if taken in the county, and returned to me, or secured so that I get them.
Martin James, Lock Lemond P. O.,
je 25--d1aw6w* Goochland county, Va.

div3.head: Twenty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Left camp, (three miles East of Richmond,) on the 8th instant, my Boy Charles, since which time I have not heard of him. He is between 40 and 45 years of age, hair slightly grey, a yellow complexion, five feet nine or ten inches high, weighs about 150 or 160 pounds, quick spoken, and his nose has the appearance of having been mashed or broken in. It may be that he has accidentally gotten with some other regiment.
Any information concerning him will be thankfully received, and the above reward paid for his delivery, either to Hon. R. R. Haynes, 119 American Hotel, or to N. C. Barton, No. 229 Main street.
Lieut. Clinton Perry.
Co. "E," 1st Texas Regiment,
je 17--1m* General Hood's Brigade.
